description:
Amazing food!! This is probably my favorite restaurant in the budget-friendly Chinatown. 
Location is great and finding parking isn't that complicated. 
Their hot and sour soup is perfectly spiced and their General's chicken is hands down the best in town. 
Their bathrooms could use some love but hey, I've never been to a restaurant in chinatown with squeaky clean services.
author: Raul R.

description:
Meh. I expected more. Off the beaten path and most definitely not touristy. And since we were the only non-Asians in this packed casual restaurant seating over 100 people --mostly Chinese families from grandmothers to infants, I thought I was in for a treat. Unfortunately and disappointedly, Chef Hung's fell short on so many counts. 

Service:  painfully slow. We waited over a half hour to receive anything at our table once we ordered. 

Food:  potstickers so doughy and tough we only ate one of the six. Singapore noodles not bad -  the best thing we ordered. Chicken and broccoli ... broccoli was good but the chicken was tiny mystery chicken chunks that seemed to come out of a Chung King can.  Hunan Beef...eh. Very wet and soupy with tough meat and not spicy at all. 

Ambiance:  a bit dirty, windowless basement setting. The best thing though was people watching the various family groups gathered around massive tables for ten or twelve enjoying their afternoon lunch.
author: Joseph P.

description:
For the fact that the food is okay, I could've give a 3 star if their service isn't that terrible. 
They showed me terrible discrimination towards customers. They were very nice to their old Chinese customers, chat and laugh with them, fill their tea cups, pack their food and check out for them fast. While they showed us their complete careless and rudeness. 
It took them more than 15mins to help us check out. I asked 4 waitresses for check and none of them responded. By the time we were waiting for our bill to come, we watched and listened to them helping and chatting with their old customers. 
I had to stand up and grab someone to get the bill and put the bill with my card back into her hand to get her check out for us. I gave them very little amount of tip because of the bad service and she finally talked to me and said "That's not enough for tips". What on earth does she think this tip thing should work! 
這麼糟糕的服務還好意思張口要小費！
author: Jing L.

description:
We tried their Cantonese style steam whole fish, which in this case was tilapia, stir fried snow pea tips, and for starters West Lake Soup. 
 The soup was hearty yet not heavy, fragrant from the cilantro and full-bodied from the finely minced beef floating in bits of egg whites.  Very good.  

The steam fish was very good when combined with the soy sauce, ginger, and scallions.

The Snow peas were prepared to perfection with bits of garlic. 

The prices were reasonable.  The service could be better but was adequate; the noisy dining room was well worn and the bathroom needed attention.
  
Overall, we'd rate it a 4.
author: Frank L.

description: The food wasn't bad but the experience was awkward. This place is located in a basement and the order takers are very rude, impatient, and do not speak English very well. Also, they started preparing their produce without cleaning it without any food handlers gloves on a table that people had just eaten off of. Also, very overpriced for such bad service.
author: Nikki D.

description:
Yikes. I could tell why this place didn't get the best safety ratings. Yet it was still bustling with business from large parties of Chinese families and friends so they must like the food.

My experience wasn't that great though. Service was slow and inattentive. We ordered prawns and flounder with tofu. The sauce on the prawns was so strong and salty I had to take a sip of tea between each bite. The tofu was really soft but the flounder was a little overcooked. There are better restaurants in Chinatown.
author: Michelle L.

description:
On a recent Sunday afternoon, my mind drew a blank in selecting what to have for lunch.  This place, eh, had that Friday... that?  Had that Wednesday.  That's the Chinatown lunch scene these days as new businesses mostly serve Szechuan or mala (numbing spiciness) cuisine.

Remembering this place, I figured if my timing was right I'd see an attractive entree on their daily specials menu.  Not seeing anything to my liking, I opted for their famed roast pork rice plate (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=9m_pLeh7kMP_Z5H0iyzy_Q&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  Served with boiled cabbage and two white rice scoops, my four thick pork slices were generously covered with brown (actually orange color) gravy.  They were tasty though one piece has a bit of an "old" taste to it (as in leftover).  Since the meal came is a small bowl of complimentary soup, I was full after three slices and packed the last one home.  The waitress forgot to offer me jello for dessert until after I asked for the bill, but I was full already anyway and passed on it.

The dining room was about half full with mostly large tables of post-church or family reunion/get together diners.  There was a smattering of tourists who came as I was leaving.  This low key basement restaurant is not easily found.  With more old time businesses closing in the neighborhood, this is one of few "Chinese American" restaurants still in business.
author: Mike C.

description: Came here for dinner while in San Fran for a family vacation. Was checking out Chinatown around dinner time and just decided to pop in. Food was mediocre, the Peking was expensive for what you got plus they didn't even cut the skin from the duck meat, just threw it all on one plate. Got more fat than actual meat and skin. Service was fast though. If I was in Chinatown again, would try a different establishment.
author: Reese W.

description: I crave Chef Hung's... 5 stars for the flavor to my taste buds.. service kinda sucks but the ladies mean well.. I love taking my grandma out to Chef Hung's cuz it's super convenient and friendly
author: Briana W.

description:
Came
Here for lunch. Ordered
The oxtail bean curd clay pot. It was excellent!!  And it only cost about $13.  Get a side of rice and you have leftovers for dinner. The gravy was delicious, the ox
Tail was tender and so was the bean curd. My go to dish to order every time I come back!!
author: Donna L.

description: Great Cantonese Chinese food in Chinatown San Francisco. The ground pork with salty fish is great. Apparently the safety rating is low, but really what good Chinese place in Chinatown isn't? Doesn't that make it more authentic? The only strange thing we ever noticed with this place was that it says it's open until 10pm and the door is open, but then you go down there at like 8:45 and they say they're closed. But then again, that kind of stuff seems to be common with Chinese places.
author: Peter K.

description: Good portion for the price. I've only tried the roast pork and oxtail lunch special and they were pretty good. Sometime it's packed during lunch time and sometime it's not, but the service is generally the same by it being average or above average for a Chinese place.
author: Wayne H.

description:
Food is good and always consistent.  But, terrible service.  They never come around and refill tea or water.  When you do, they have an attitude, except for one waitress.  Don't have her name.  I usually tip her extra, and tell her.....that's only for her.
They always give you dessert, if they like you.  When you ask for dessert, they say they don't have it today.  But, you'll see other people get them.
author: Carole L.

description:
Whenever I try a new Chinese restaurant, I like to order House Special Chow Mein Hong Kong Style (with pan fried noodles).  Here it's $10.95

This dish gives the restaurant a chance to show what they can do, and the types of meats and vegetables they like to use.

The woman that waited on me was nice, and I made it a point to say it was my first time, I was a local, not a tourist, and that I'd come back if I liked it.

As soon as they brought me my take out bag, I could smell a strong odor (which isn't always bad).  However, once I got to open up the container to eat it, the strong odor ended up being the iodine smell off the 2 shrimp and a bunch of cut up calamari!  The Chef who threw those ingredients into my dish must have either lost his sense of smell, or didn't care if I ever came back.

In any case, because of that, this restaurant showed me that it's not worth my time to ever go back.  The iodine smell was so strong, any normal person should have been able to smell it.

As for the other ingredients, the scallops were small, but OK, and the chicken tasted OK.  The BBQ pork was really bland and didn't seem freshly purchased.  They only used bok choy as the vegetable.  The pan fried noodles were pretty good, and the sauce was just OK.

Fortunately, I like several other restaurants in Chinatown.  So, I won't go hungry...
author: Roy C.

description: This is pretty classic Chinese food. Chinese style. With fluorescents and Chinese tables. Not glamorous but the food is cheap. I usually get Soup here and it is consistently good.
author: Doug W.

description: Food okay for price. Service terrible! Not a clean restaurant
author: dan w.

description: My husband and I were looking for real Chinese food. The first couple of restaurants we found on Yelp were too trendy for our taste. Chef Hung's was the hole in the wall we were looking for.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Why am I not surprised at the poor health inspection score here? After all, you climb down a flight of worn stairs into a basement to eat here. You immediately see the familiar round tables with pink tablecloths that you see at almost every restaurant in Chinatown. Finding a table for one is always a challenge, so I was cloistered in the corner away from the big parties with a humongous menu that took a while to peruse. They basically serve everything you would expect from a Chinese restaurant including Egg Foo Young and Congee. However, I had my eye out for the one elusive dish that I am beginning to see more of in the area, steamed chicken. Hunan Homes makes a good one.

But they're often crowded with tour bus groups, so I was looking for alternatives. On the menu, I saw "Chicken with Ginger Onion Sauce", a half one for $8.95. Could it be? I interrogated the harried waitress who nodded her head in response to my question about whether the chicken was steamed or not. Out it came, and much to my delight, it was a heaping plate of steamed chicken doused with soy sauce, covered with shredded green onions and with minced ginger and garlic on the side (photo: http://bit.ly/1RGdRV1). It really hit the spot with the white meat not remotely dry, the dark meat quite moist and the skin not too rubbery. I was not as big a fan of their $6.95 Potstickers. No complaints about the portion as the order is a half-dozen extra large ones (photo: http://bit.ly/1Hk3sc7).

However, I found the wrappers just way too thick and chewy for my taste. I liked the chicken enough to come back with Jamie W. a couple of months later, and in addition to my chicken dish, we ordered the $9.95 General's Chicken, which he deemed as good as the one served at Red Jade, high praise indeed for such a saucy creation (photo: http://bit.ly/1GTugoS). We also tried the $8.95 Fried Calamari, which came in a heaping pile, very hot from the fryer, and pretty tasty (photo: http://bit.ly/1NJvwuc). It wasn't too chewy though we really didn't need the little puddle of cherry sauce which is apparently de rigeur for this dish. Cleanliness may not be close to godliness at this Chinatown basement operation, but I may take my chances again with that steamed chicken when I feel a hankering.

FOOD - 3 stars...despite excellent steamed chicken, I do have to ding them a star for the health inspection score...and those chewy potsticker wrappers, too
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...well, it's a basement
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...actually quite nice once you get into their view
TOTAL - 3 stars...please improve your score so I can feel secure about the quality of that steamed chicken
author: Ed U.

description:
Chef Hung's is a great place for a casual lunch with great Chinese food at very low prices!

First off, it's not the cleanest of places nor is the service the best. If you did not already assume that, welcome to Chinatown!

What makes this place special is the great food at a bargain price. I could see some of the lunch specials being sold at a food truck or similar restaurant for double the price and nearly half the portion. Most daily lunch specials come around $6.75 and comes with soup, coffee, and jello. Not only that, the food is cooked well and tastes far better than what the price might suggest.

Some recommended dishes to get here include the filet of sole, beef tongue, roast pork, and ham hock lunch specials. All of them come with rice and cabbage. The beef tongue and roast pork come with a delicious thick gravy. The filet of sole comes with tar tar sauce. The ham comes on a giant bone where the meat is full of flavor. The portion sizes here are also fairly generous.
author: Joshua M.

description: This is a hole in the wall spot in Chinatown. The food is quite tasty and I would recommend the fried cod. Food came out quick and service was pretty efficient.
author: Brian G.

description:
This restaurant does not have an ambiance unless you count Spartan as an ambiance.
  The ingredients were fresh, food was served fast and well prepared. Best General's or General Tsao chicken I have eaten. Also Sweet and Sour Pork was quite good and probably the best I have eaten.
  Highly recommended as a dining establishment!
  The staff was prepping food in the dining room as we ate and most of the patrons were obviously locals. The ethnicity of the patrons speaks well of their standing with the community of Chinatown.
author: P.J. H.

description:
Food is okay, service needs much work.  I ate at Chef Hung's with several families with very young kids in November 2016 as we'd been there previously and they were one of the few restaurants open fairly late on a Friday night. The waitress pushed food on us, insisting that we weren't ordering enough, and recommended some of pricier items like shrimp in wine sauce which consisted of about six small shrimp and a lot of celery for $13.  As a result, we had a ton of leftovers.  

As others have reported, she later harangued us for a larger tip...!  Feeling bullied, we relented, just wanting to leave, but will definitely never patronize Chef Hung's again.  As cleanliness is also a major issue, it's best to avoid this place.
author: Kevin W.

description:
"A person needs new experiences. They jar something deep inside, allowing you to grow. Without them, it sleeps- seldom to awaken. The sleeper must awaken. " 
Frank Herbert

Interesting place.  Reminded me of my college days and the trips to TJ with the guys on the street beckoning you to walk down to the basement for 5 beers for $5 but here there is just a sign...  Relatives wanted to meet here for dinner so I enter.

I ordered my old faithful char sui pan fried noodles.  The char sui was excellent as was the sauce and bok choy.  The egg noodles were good but not great.  The blend of flavors I found to be very good.  I prefer the egg noodles at Great Eastern.

The fried pork chops were also very good.  The flavor was very good to excellent but the one thing that I didn't like was there was too much fat.  It was chewy and I didn't want to swallow but I was with the relatives so I didn't want everyone watching me spit it out...

The soy sauce chicken was awesome!  The chicken was perfectly cooked, tender, juicy, and filled with just the right amount of soy sauce flavor.  Never eaten soy sauce chicken this good in San Diego...

The chinese sausage over rice was excellent.  I'm curious where they get their chinese sausage at as it had this amazing flavor and texture which made me feel guilty for eating all the crappy supermarket chinese sausage over the years...

The broccoli was excellent.  It appeared steamed or stir fried but tasted perfect.  I try making broccoli all the time but it taste a bit bland or too much soy sauce, or starchy, or gingery, or something.  If I could make broccoli this good I could go vegetarian.

To conclude this place looks like a hole in the wall but the food is very good to great and the prices are good.
author: Soo H.

description: despite poor reviews and food safety warning, this was some of the best chinese food i've ever had!!! the pork fried rice and mongolian beef chow mein were to die for, you get so much food for such a decent price it's more than worth it! a lil dirty on the inside but not unbearable. next time i'm in the bay area i'll be back for sure
author: Taylor R.

description:
This place is totally A-OK!  

The food is pretty yummy, the prices are pretty reasonable, the service is pretty friendly and quick, and the interior looks like a takeout place with tons of room and nicer chairs.

We wandered in for a snack while exploring Chinatown and split some shrimp chow mein.  It was definitely tasty but fell short of spectacular.  The tea was nice and we left full.
author: Irina H.

description: As you descend into the basement of Chef Hung's you might be wondering "did this place pass their food inspection? " and the definitive answer is "who the hell knows? ". The food tasted ok, but there's just no reason to go here with so many other great options available. If you're craving Panda Express or something like that, this is going to be you're go to stop.
author: Eric M.

description: We parked near this restaurant for lunch during rush hour.  Well, we were in luck when we stopped inside.  The waitress helped out my mom and dad to order some noodle dishes.  Well, the service was fast and good.  We were able to get our meal relatively fast and it was a little after noon.  So, we were pretty hungry after touring Japantown.  My favorite would have to be the beef noodle soup.
author: Phillip Y.

description: Took my class of special needs students out for Chinese New Year and decided to eat here. The service was slow and inattentive despite a fairly empty dining room. We paid the bill and were just about to leave as the server decided to harass us for a larger tip! If this is any indication of Chinese culture, there is no honor!
author: Justin B.

description:
Not worth your time
1. We walked in and it literally went downhill
2. They asked for our order four different times by four different people after we had already ordered. And then I started questioning, "did I really order my food?!" I was trying to get Chinese food not play Chinese checkers. The feng shui was very off. It was a reminder of a school cafeteria.
3.  While we were waiting for our food, they walked with the trash can in the middle of the restaurant without going around which caused the place to smell. I lost my appetite before I received my food.
4.  We ordered the BBQ pork and chicken chow mein. The chicken was dry, the pork was cold, and don't get me started on the mushrooms. Even though they weren't magic mushrooms, I still had a bad trip. And the chow mein was really greasy, it made our lips super sticky, we tried to converse but nothing came out. 
5. Once we asked for the bill, they looked at us and said "not ready" and walked away. And when we gave her the money for the bill. She said, "one more dollar" and literally ripped the dollar out of my hand. I'm now scarred...
Not worth your money
author: Natalia F.

description:
For authentic Chinese food, you've gotta try this place out.  Not fancy, but the food definitely makes up for that.

Not to mention, the portions are huge, so you're not gonna leave hungry.

I'd highly recommend this place for great Chinese food in San Francisco.
author: Greg W.

description: Not worth your time. Food is mediocre at best and they chase you out for a tip when the service isn't even good. DO NOT GO HERE!!! I made the mistake of going without reading the reviews on yelp! Hope I can save someone money & their time.
author: Kimberly L.

description: This is literally a hole in the wall. But the food was yummy. I had the rock cod with black bean sauce lunch special. A lot of food for $7.50! Delicious fish, fresh and tasty. I would definitely recommend this place!
author: Bonny P.

description:
Went there for lunch during our two-day holiday in SF. The food is really good and large portions. The service, however, is not. The waitress is rude and took our plates literally one second after we put down our chopsticks. She was so careless that the plates hit my cellphone and charging cable when she took them away. Charging cable became sticky because of whatever came out of the plates when she rudely took them. And worst of all, absolutely no apology! 

My advise for people with Chinese background, if you do not speak Cantonese, simply take the food away or choose a better alternative! Don't let any discriminative waitress ruin your lunch or dinner!
author: Wuyi W.

description: Egg drop soup is good. But the food gave us serious stomach upset. Tried to charge us more for our bill and added on extra charges. Not worth the money. I left feeling very frustrated that we paid as much as we did for the food we received.
author: Laurel B.

description:
Bad service, foods so so, not recommended

We search from Google, found that this restaurant has 4.4 rate out of 5. They really have a long list of Chinese foods but the taste is just so so. The worst part I dislike is their service. They chase us for tips but seriously they don't deserve it!
author: Chloe Y.

description:
The food is always on point! I have been going there for 7 years every time i am in SF. I have never gotten sick. 

Hopefully they get on board with the inspection stuff...
author: Georgina M.

description: The service was laughable at best and when I decided not to tip the server ran up the block after me and demanded a tip if I could rate any lower I would
author: Adonayn O.

description:
I came here for brunch on a weekday. 

The waitress was super friendly!!!! 
We ordered 2 lunch specials ( beef tongue & corn beef) , and I got the beef chow fun ( goun chau ngau ho). 

The lunch specials were so weird.... a huge bowl of rice, boiled cabbage, and slices of beef tongue and corn beef with some weird sauce on them.  I have never seen such unattractive looking food in my life. 
It didn't taste bad, but it was just so weird to look at that i probably wouldn't order it... I am not that fond of boiled cabbage . 

The beef chow fun was oily and delicious!! Just the way I like it !

The meal was so affordable only $22 and we had lots of extra chow fun to take home. 

The table across from us ( mostly seniors around 60 and up) was drinking cognac with their brunch HAHAHA it was not even noon and these men were already drinking.. I wish i had taken a picture.
author: Tiffany Y.

description: Great food.  My wife and I haven't had good Chinese food in like 6 months, so thank god for Chinatown in San Francisco.  If you are down here, this is definitely a frat place to eat, check it out :)
author: Rob D.

description: Bad service. Stopped by with coworkers.  We all ordered rice plates. However, mine was brought out 10 minutes later than everyone else's. We had a party of 3. It was ridiculous considering the restaurant wasn't even half way full.   My coworkers are Chinese. I'm not. I guess it was more important for them to get served before me. I would never spend another cent in this place.
author: JustMe D.

description:
One of our favorite places in China Town...this is the only place that makes authentic beef broccoli! Reminds so much of my childhood in China Town Manila. 

Beef Broccoli- cooked with ginger and not too much soy sauce. Beef is tender!
Salt and Pepper Chops - Crispy, not too salty and perfectly spiced.
Walnut Prawns - Yum!
Curry chicken clay pot- perfectly spiced!

Good portion serving and good for families! 

Place is small and it can get crowded.
author: Shiela C.

description: Came here for dinner with the fam. My parents asked me what I was craving and I was on a seafood kick, so I wanted ginger scallion crab or steamed fish in soy sauce. They were out of both! So we ended up getting a bunch of clay pots. The dishes are a decent size and the clay pots were good. My parents love the rice pots with toppings so we ordered two of those. The rice had a nice crustiness to it and the toppings flavored the rice nicely. The roast pork and oyster clay pot we got had a good amount of meat, oysters and veggies. Service was like any other chinese restaurant. Quick and efficient. I would have given them 3.5 stars, rounded up to 4 stars, but since they didn't have two of the dishes I was craving, they go down to a solid 3 stars!
author: Elena N.

description: I will never go back to this restaurant again! Shitty customer service! One of their waitresses still taught me and my friends how to eat our rice with only fork and knife #facepalm #unlike
author: Yi Hui K.

description: Food is so so and customer service need to be improved! The waitress chase us all the way from restaurant just to get tips from us but they didn't deserved that!
author: Ivy C.

description:
Bad food they are not honest will not go back again
Do not go to this place we are ordered tilapia we count
How may fish were in the tank we saw the chaf  scooped a life fish then put it back in the different tank
And served us unfresh fish we complain but they insisted there had most fresh fish
author: Kelley K.

description:
Great food!! Visiting from out of town and wanted an "authentic" Chinatown feel with amazing food...well that's what we got!

Great atmosphere...seemed like tons of locals.

Food- exactly what we hoped for. The Egg Drop soup was amazing-- much different than we are used to. It was more like a combination of the egg drop soup I'm used to but with veggies and a lighter broth. Potstickers were okay...probably the one thing I wasn't super impressed with. However the Lemon Chicken was the best I've ever had and the Mongolian beef was spectacular. Also we got chicken fried rice which was excellent.

Service- not bad. The service was very "matter of fact"...basically the waiters didn't BS with you but were always making sure the consumers had what they needed.

Overall- highly recommend!!
author: Alex K.

description: From Vegas visiting and wanted a late night Chinese spot in Chinatown and I picked the perfect one ! Fried flounder was on point! War wonton soup what's the best ever taste!
author: Darrio R.

description: Excellent Chinese food and very hospitable service. Felt like we were in China. Authentic and very tasty.
author: Jay S.

description: We came to the restaurant around 3pm in the afternoon. Nobody comes to serve us for twenty minutes. We ordered some noodle, pork rib and fish in chili oil. Everything tastes like salt. The fish smells perished. Definitely would not come back.
author: Yuji M.

description: We visited this restaurant blind and were glad we did. It was bustling w/ Chinese-speaking locals late on a Sunday night. The food was delicious....I especially loved the chicken with black pepper lo mein. Yum.
author: Mary Beth L.

description:
The food was fine. We ordered sweet and sour chicken, orange chicken, and fried rice. The Mongolian beef seemed very fatty. 
The upstairs bathrooms were filthy and we actually saw a large rat upstairs, which then tried to venture down the stairs. The waitress shooed it away and then brought us the bill. Whaaaat????  No offer to even comp our meal!!  Will not return!
author: Lisa A.

description:
We went to Chef Hung's in SF Chinatown for dinner.  Old school Cantonese food restaurant.

Place had only 3 tables eating at 6pm on Sat 1/23/10 so we lucked out.  Only one waitress at the time, but then others showed up.

We got:

FREE hot tea - ok

Snow peas, mushroom & water chestnuts $8.95 - B. liked it, I thought it was just ok.  Lots of mushrooms from a can.

Fu Kien style fried rice $7.25 - it's a Funny name.  It's goopy sauce w/ tiny scallops, egg, mushrooms over fried rice.  We liked it.

big pea sprouts w/ garlic $11.95 I didn't ask the price - yikes.  It was tasty though.

oxtail w/ bean curd in clay pot $8.95 - tasty oxtail, but not tender enough.  Good sauce.

Saw fish tanks - didn't get any fresh fish/crab.

$37.10 + $3.55 tax = $40.65 before tip for 4 dishes & lots of leftovers.  Credit cards taken over $15.  Fortune cookies given w/ bill.

Bathrooms: Separate upstairs.

Tip: If you want a cheap dinner you can get anything from the Lunch Special menu for an additional 50c.  That's so cool.  Lunch hrs 11-5pm daily and range from 6-6.95.

Recommended if you want cheap Chinese food in SF Chinatown.
author: Ann L.

description: Everything about this establishment is ordinary. The decor is ordinary, the food is ordinary and service is okay. Reasonable prices. I'm glad I ate before using the bathroom. It was despicable. I would have lost my appetite. I just hope the kitchen is cleaner than their bathrooms!
author: Michael R.

description: bad service. waitresses were gossiping more than checking up on you. gave other parties had more attention than us. gave attitude when no tip was given.
author: Alina A.

description:
Ordered the Hong Kong special for minimum of two ppl, enough for four.
The sweet and sour chicken was great, the broccoli beef was ok, the wonton soup was delicious. Service was great!! Very friendly staff:)
author: Arlene B.

description: We didn't see the health warning until after we ordered! However, we stayed and enjoyed our meal. Egg rolls were so good and deep fried perfectly and came with a sweet sauce for dipping similar to a sweet and sour sauce. Yum!!! Wonton soup and the tomato beef were not what we were expecting but it was alright. Tomato beef was in a reddish orange sauce that was semi sweet and had bell peppers and onions as well. Orange chicken had a good flavor but was slightly over cooked. There were tons of locals there as well as tourists. The place was packed. The place is old and not updated but tables were clean and waitstaff were very nice.
author: Michelle M.

description:
This is my first review, but when a place this good comes along, you just have to. My friend and I are road tripping across the west and stumbled upon this place.

The ambience is decent and definitely feels authentically Chinese. Walk down some stairs to get in and be greeted instantly. We came for lunch both times, so it may be busier at other times. 

Free jasmine tea was great. And the appetizers (especially the egg rolls and pot stickers) were cooked homemade. The entrees were terrific as well. The sweet and sour chicken was heavy on the sauce and a bit light on the chicken, but still very delicious. 

My only complaints: they don't do special orders and the bathrooms were dirty and reeked. Get past that and you're in for a treat!
author: Benjamin M.

description: Best family Chinese food in San Francisco . Great chicken fried rice. We ordered with no veggies. Slow service but think it's because they take their time w preparation. Very authentic surroundings. Excellent beef and broccoli. Sweet and sour chicken very tasty. Chicken chow mein is fabulous. Kids loved it and are picky eaters!
author: Michelle L.

description: Maybe it was the night but we found the staff to be indifferent, bordering on rude, and the food was marginal at best.  Chinese cuisine can be wonderful, this was definitely not that.  Ambience non existent and felt like if you were not a local you really did not count.  Drop a few blocks down to the Embarcadero to Osha Thai if you happen to like  Thai food, everything this place was not, or if you are in the mood for Italian check out Il Casario Pizzeria over on Columbus that too turned out to be wonderful.
author: RW B.

description: We are her last night and it was fabulous. The service and food were amazing. We had the pork fried rice, Generajs chicken and BBQ pork egg foo yung. Very traditional and authentic Chinese. Best I've ever had personally.
author: Geri S.

description:
Dirty dishes and dirty atmosphere! YUCK!

$15 minimum purchase for credit card use

The food I have to admit is pretty good.  The main cook is a good family friend.  
Its just so darn expensive compared to LA! More than double...grrz....
author: David W.

description:
--------LUNCH ONLY-----------
Walk by this place all the time but miss it because it's stairs leading down to a basement. Anyway, came here for lunch and their lunch daily special selection is pretty solid. Ordered the scrambled egg shrimp with rice which is a pretty generous dish for less than $7. If you're just a tourist visiting, this isn't a place to come to because it's not anything special. BUT if you work/live in the area and want some good, fast Chinese food, then I think this is place is legit. Plus there's never a wait so that's a even bigger plus.
author: Diana Y.

description: This place used to be Great Wall of China Chinese Restaurant, but I guess they've changed it since the last time my family frequented the space. It's still underground and pretty dirty, so that much hasn't changed. Super greasy, MSG-laden, salty, and glossy. This is Americanized Chinese food at some of its worst. It's dirt-cheap, and the portions are great, but this is not an authentic meal by any means. They cater to American patrons, as can be seen by the super glossy plates and wrong meal order served.
author: Danny C.

description: Chef Hung doesn't skimp on his portions. With a generous... meaty, heart, he serves bonerfied Chinese food that all the ladies love.
author: Steven T.

description: We wanted good, inexpensive, and quick Chinese food in a casual setting. We found this place off Yelp and it was just what we were looking for. Portions are even larger than expected. Their spicy food is SPICY, so be careful. No wait to sit. Menu is also in English and some of the ladies know English better than others. I wish we had a fridge and microwave in our hotel room so we could take the leftovers. Really great experience - will come back next time we visit.
author: Laura O.

description: Food was COLD and tasted like it's old. Poor service didn't help either, we asked for two diet cokes and the waitress brought two cans dropping it in front of each of us and walked away! No cups or straws...
author: Navid S.

description: The food has always been excellent here. Good authentic Chinese, freshly made with generous portions.  You go here for the food, any the atmosphere. It is like a Chinese diner.
author: Susan K.

description:
I love hole in the wall restaurants, oops.. this is a hole in the ground restaurant - you walk down a flight of stairs from the sidewalk level to get to this basement level restaurant.

I've worked off and on in the financial district for over 5 years and have tasted my fair (fear?) share of bad to good cantonese food.  The food is GOOD here!  Lots of patrons, ranging from tourists to business people to retired cantonese locals.  Good tell tale sign of a decent cantonese restaurant.

I had the Hong Too Yee Foo Won Ton for lunch at $6.95.  This is cheap and really a good deal considering the preparation involved in making this dish.... I mean bowl.  This won ton is not found  in many SF cantonese restaurants due to the time it takes to produce. 

Imagine, fried won ton in a bowl of Westlake minced pork & duck (not beef) soup.  I love the cilantro and egg whites that are typically part of a Westlake soup.    

As to the service, the waitresses are nice here, apologizing for not bringing tea in a timely basis and they also do not talk behind your back thinking that you don't speak or understand cantonese.  HEAR THIS YOUNG'S CAFE ON KEARNEY AND SACRAMENTO!  Don't say the bald guy!  Although, I have shaved my head down to a "two"....LOL.

Go to Hung's for good service and good food!  Not fine dining but a "find" in dining.
author: Scott L.

description: I love this place! Came here the other day with my boyfriend. We ordered the mongolian beef lunch special (which came with rice), and a beef chow fun. I like how they added fresh jalapenos with their green peppers and onions in the mongolian beef. The beef was also so tender! They also gave you a lot of meat in the chow fun. We really like this place! The beef chow fun was about $6.75 and the mongolian beef was about $6.50 I think. The portions were decent. I would definitely come here again!
author: Kari L.

description: I love buying take out and occasionally eat at there. Awesome service and great Chinese and American food.
author: Joseph C.

description: Really tasty food and not very greasy (which is good). Hot n sour soup had a tasty umami flavor. Pork fried rice was extremely satisfying. We also got a soft tofu and stir fried bok choy dish that was the star. Their chow funn noodles were sub par but that was their only fault. Friendly service and cheap prices. Now I know where to get great Chinese food in Chinatown when I visit.
author: Flavia A.

description: Horrible service, and are very expensive in both food and drinks. When I attended this restaurant, we were given a dirty table that wasn't set up like the rest. The food is very small portions. The BBQ pork fried rice was cold, the Orange chicken and Mongolian beef were overcooked, and the egg rolls were overcooked as well. When we finished our food we waited a long time for the bill, and as well as waiting to give them our money. The restaurant itself is unsanitary. I wouldn't recommend this restaurant if you are looking for an authentic and clean Chinese restaurant. I would give it 0 stars if possible.
author: Ariel C.

description: What a great place for the best Chinese food.  The looks of the place is nothing fancy and it will probably have some turn away. If you truly want great foo then eat here!! The only thing I would ask for is better restroom facilities and that is the only reason I rated this 4 stars but rest assure the food is nothing but 5 stars!! We will be back the next time we are in San Francisco.
author: Connie B.

description:
SURPRISINGLY, not bad! 

Arrived at 5pm for dinner and was beyond shocked, to see an empty restaurant. However, once 6 hit, the restaurant quickly filled and there was a wait out the door! 

Do not let the appearance fool you. This is definitely one of those places where food tastes decent even though you're going down into a basement level. The food was delicious... however the shark fin.. I would totally pass on next time. We felt there was an ingredient in there that was once dehydrated that totally threw the texture and taste off. 

A must try.. but don't expect ambiance.
author: Deanna G.

description: I always say, you know if a chinese restaurant serves good food if they make good chow fun, and this place makes a good one! Ordered their beef chow fun (wet, gravy style) to go for dinner and it was delicious. Their noodles and sauce tasted just right but their beef is ok. Costed $8 which is a decent price. Would definitely go back to try other dishes on their menu.
author: C L.

description: The food was ok, but the concern I have is for anyone with peanut allergies. We specifically asked SEVERAL times if there were peanuts in any of the dishes we ordered. We even made sure that there wasn't peanut oil in the salad, and the waitresses assured us multiple times that everything would be safe for our friend with the peanut allergy to eat. But less than 10 minutes after we left the restaurant, our friend had a really severe reaction, and we had to call 911. It was very frustrating that the wait staff told us it was perfectly safe for him to eat, when really it wasn't.
author: Maleah M.

description:
I came here several times for lunch. It may be a small underground restaurant, it is a pretty good place for lunch and to hang out!!! 

Chef Hung's Restaurant makes pretty good Rice Plates. The Rice Plates that, I tried woud be the beef with oyster over rice, beef with raw egg over rice, sweet & sour pork over rice, chicken w/ salted fish fried rice.  

I also like the free jello that they give you when you finish your lunch!!!
Chef Hungs Restaurant Staff are very friendly!!!
author: William B.

description:
Admittedly I judge places by the look. I wouldn't have walked into it if not recommendation by a friend. We got the eggplant claypot (with salty fish?) and steamed fish. They came out exactly how they should be in china!

Big fan from now on!
author: Sans S.

description:
This restaurant has a low-light feel to the place; sorta like the Chinese restaurant from the movie Glengarry Glen Ross.

The food was ok.  I had the black-bean beef "tips" lunch plate.  The portions are good.  It filled my stomach nicely.

I chuckled at the name and marvelled at several other Chinese restaurants where the name just makes me giggle (A-Dong, King Dong, Fuku Sushi).

I would eat there again...
author: Derek N.

description:
We got the Szechuan Dinner for 2 ($13.95 each) which is a great deal but there are definitely better spots in Chinatown...

Pork Fried Rice: too dry.
Mongolian Beef: too chewy.
Chicken: too much batter and sauce.
Sweet and Sour Soup: too... too something.  

Plus side: Huge portions.  Cheap.  Friendly.  Fast.
author: Anh D.

description:
Cheap and Filling. Get a full meal with soup, entree, rice or noodle, and dessert for less than $8. Went with the Filet of Sole and it was a generous portion (of course frozen seafood and not fresh for this price). 

Service was acceptable for Chinese standards.
author: Dustin T.

description:
Yea real good!
Bring a crowd and get the big table by the big screen TV....
great food and you won't hafta miss any games.

*****daily specials served on large plates...
Fillet of sole (large fluffy portions) with rice and veggies my fav!

Oops take a few stars away.  Last visit not very tasty.
Cooks night off maybe...oh well plenty of other places to try.
author: Cee G.

description: Nice, little quaint back alley Chinese in the middle of Chinatown. Really good value for money, I was bloody hungry after walking the city all day and couldn't finish my main. Really nice, cheap food and good service.
author: Ryan P.

description:
Was in San Fran for work and loved this place so much I went twice in the span of 3 days.  The food was great and the people were very nice.  
It is nothing fancy - your soda comes from a can - but don't let that keep you away.  The casual atmosphere was part of the charm of the place. 
Definitely recommend!
author: Jessica L.

description:
I loved it. For a while on our early Sunday afternoon visit we were the only English speaking customers in the place, and there were what appeared to be a couple of large families at round tables talking, laughing, and eating. I felt like we were getting a true Chinatown experience.

We had roast duck (my first time with duck) and rice plus eggrolls. I liked it a lot, but my wife thought it too gamey. It had a semisweet glaze and the best pieces were tender and juicy.

The only negative, and not necessarily their fault, is that everything is ala carte. At the Chinese restaurants I've been to before, you always get vegetables with anything you order, so I was expecting some vegetables with the duck.
author: Doug W.

description: Decided to try the food at this restaurant and it was DELICIOUS. Love the Mongolian Beef and the Chicken Chow Mein. The staff's were really nice and very efficient, prices were reasonable. I would highly recommend the Westlake minced soup and the Walnut Prawn dish. One of the best Chinese restaurants in SF
author: Natalie G.

description: Some of the best Chinese food I've ever had. Stopped by on my trip from New York. Family style food at reasonable prices. Get the chicken fried rice.
author: Jeff S.

description:
This place blew my mind.
Best Chinese in the US.
Get the beef fried rice.
author: Josh G.

description: First time here, not too impressed. I ordered three things and none if them were that good. First, the fried rice was made with cabbage. I've never had it like that and I thought it was gross. Next, I ordered the Mongolian Beef, which wasn't too bad, a little salty. Lastly, I ordered the Sweet n Sour Pork and the breading was hard and burnt tasting, the sauce didn't help mask the horrible flavor. Not a good first impression of this place, and there are a thousand other Chinese food shops within seconds I will try next time before returning here.
author: Jaime B.

description:
I was in San Fran on business and staying in Chinatown, so I wondered out and happened upon this place.  

The decor is nothing to write home about, but I don't really care about decor, so I was fine with it.

When I walked in I noticed that everyone else in the place was speaking Chinese, so I took that as a good sign.

I ordered the dinner special which came with tea, soup, an egg roll, chicken salad, pork fried rice and I chose the shredded pork.  Here's what I thought about the food:

Tea - A little bland.

Soup - I'm not sure what kind of soup it was, but it had a lot of vegetables (cabbage, mushrooms, celery, etc.) and egg.  I was worried that it would be too oily, but it was not at all.  The flavor wasn't quite strong enough, but the vegetables were cooked perfectly and tasted very fresh.

Chicken Salad - This was not like any chicken salad I've had before.  It was very simple - shredded lettuce, dried noodles and breaded and fried chicken.  There was a light sesame dressing the the chicken was warm and fresh.  

Egg Roll - Big, not too hot, full of good pork and veggies and it didn't make my napkin translucent when I set it on there for 10 seconds.

Pork Fried Rice - As a heads up, I'm  not really a big fried rice guy.  It wasn't too flavorful (although, I always feel that way about fried rice), but there was a lot of pork in it.

Shredded Pork - This was fantastic.  It was perfectly spicy (my nose got a little runny, but I didn't start sweating).  The dish contained pork, noodles, onions, peppers and mushrooms.  It was garlic flavored and a tad sweet.  I was already really full after eating everything else, but had to finish it and dragged myself home, food-comatose.

Overall, the service was good, the food was good, the portions were large and the prices was right.  Next time I'm up in SF I'll definitely stop back here.
author: Jake W.

description:
favorite dish - West Lake Minced Beef Soup

Chinatown on a weeknite is pretty dull.  The shops close up early and there aren't many tourists roaming the streets unless you are like me.  Always looking for an authentic meal to escape all the flashiness of the tourist trap restaurants.  There are still many restaurants open during the time I went roaming for dinner.  I didn't want to let my hunger get the best of me so my GF and I decided to walk around a bit to find the tastiest choice.  After roaming for an hour, we decided on Chef Hung's because there were lots of people inside.  And not just anyone; there were lots of Chinese people inside and maybe a couple of tourists at most.  I figure, this place has to be good quality and value since most of their customers are locals.  And I was right.

The food here is like comfort food for me.  HK style Chinese food.  No, I'm not a Honger but my best buddies are.  So are my roommates.  I'm fully exposed to HK food and Chef Hung's can hold its own in my book.  I will definitely be coming back here the next time I visit SF.
author: Mike C.

description: This place is excellent! Of the million chinese restaurants in china town, i chose this one because i had read previous ratings that were listed and many of the restaurants didn't show online ratings. The place was very clean. I ordered Eggrolls (3) and an entree of General Tso chicken. Both were amazing and came with green tea. The food was excellent and the presentation was good as well. The staff there was also very friendly and struck up a conversation instantly. I really enjoyed myself at this restaurant. Not to mention, the prices weren't bad at all!
author: James O.

description:
We were looking for a Chinese restaurant to eat at in China town.  Hmmm....which one should we try?  We were looking for a place that wasn't empty looking and not too pricey.  We stumbled across this underground joint (literally) on Clay.  The dining area was packed with many locals and large parties.  The wait was not that long...people were walking out in groups.  

I was wondering why people kept telling ME that this place is great.....as they were leaving.  Two people told me to try the salt fish and pork dish.  Maybe people thought that I wasn't from California.  I realized that I was wearing a San Francisco sweater (with large font), looking like a tourist standing in front of the menu board.  I forgot my sweater in San Jose, so I ended up buying one from a vendor for $10 down the street.  

Service here was good considering a limited staff with a crowded room. Prices here are more reasonable than others in the area.  We ordered the fried calamari, Chinese broccoli, deep fried flounder, and their salt fish with shredded pork dish - the local's recommendation.  First off, I was not impressed with their fried calamari.  Their broccoli and flounder was pretty good.  The flounder could've been crispier though.  The salt fish and shredded pork dish was a disappointment.  It had a funny smell to it too.  I think the locals were just messin with me.
author: Bobby L.

description: A mediocre meal. For less, there are better meals in China town.
author: Andrew H.

description: We ordered quite a feast here.  The stars of the show were the Beef and Broccoli, the Potstickers, and the Curry Chicken with Coconut Sauce.  Freaking delicious.
author: David P.

description:
Good hole in wall place in SF Chinatown to eat cheap. Mix of authentic Chinese & comfort food daily specials - ox tail, beef tongue, etc.

Pros
- daily special : I had the oxtail stew ($7) & my dad had the beef tongue ($8) - soup, coffee, toast, jello included.
- large portions
- nice service

Cons
- street parking

Return Visit
- yes - it's one of my folks favorites.
author: X L.

description: It's been four years since I wrote my first review and after reading some of the other reviews I think it's time for an update.  Chef Hung's has changed hands since last time and some of the wait staff is also different.  Nevertheless it is still a great value for the money.  If you go there on a Sunday (try to beat the church crowd) they have amazing values for individual plates that anyone would be hard pressed to finish.  I still go there regularly with my group -- probably about 40 times since my last review.  As far as parking is concerned, there is very limited street parking in Chinatown.  If you're lucky you'll find a place in back at the Waverly Place entrance.  I have only found street parking once in over 40 years of trying.  Where I usually park is the parking garage under Portsmouth Square about three blocks away.  There's also parking under Saint Mary's square on California.  For the person with the friend that had an allergic reaction to peanuts -- don't blame it on Chef Hungs.  I would strongly encourage you to never eat Chinese food in a genuine Chinese restaurant.  If you ask the waitress if they use peanuts, of course they would say no unless it's specifically a peanut dish but the pots and pans probably come in contact with peanuts from time to time as does every single restaurant in Chinatown and 99.999% of any restaurant that serves genuine Asian fare.  That's just the way it is.  Besides, the waitress doesn't always understand what you're trying to ask.  Bottom line, Chef Hungs is still a good value with large portions and tasty food.
author: Robert H.

description: The people are pretty nice here and the portions are pretty big. In my opinion I think the food is pretty good, though I only get clay pot rice. Get a small though. It's more than big enough for one person, and a medium is definitely more than enough for two. I'm almost afraid to see how big a large is..
author: Jennifer J.

description:
Quick, tasty, & cheap lunch specials.
Stopped in here after being mistakenly sent to The Wok Shop & the owner recommended this spot for lunch.
Will definitely bring back future visitors to chinatown with me!
author: Nici G.

description:
Chef Hung's gets 4 stars for meeting (but not exceeding) my Chinatown criteria: nothing visibly gross / unclean, primarily Asian patrons, reasonably good food for the price, and didn't get sick later. 

I went with two coworkers for Chinese New Year and we split a few dishes, Mongolian chicken, some kind of beef and fried flat noodle dish and egg foo young. They also include tea for free. Everything was pretty okay, nothing remarkable but I would come back.

Don't stop here if you're in a hurry though, it took a while to pay the bill and get going.
author: Beth D.

description:
I've eaten here twice & both times the food is solid!  The place is underground (literally).  There are steps so beware if you have a stroller.  Make sure to order the King Do since its not on the menu.  Its basically sweet & sour spareribs cooked to perfection!  

Tip:  they validate for parking.  I forgot the name, but its the one where the elevators are in the park.  So you'll end up w/ free parking!
author: Jo B.

description:
Please turn away as this review is not suitable for all audiences. 

This is the most disgusting restaurant I've ever eaten in anywhere.  That goes for remote places in Mexico AND Asia.  Like a previous poster mentioned we went on New Years... 2/14/10 so my wife thought this was a good place.  Her father and I refused to go in, she had to drag us in.  I said in my most polite voice, "you've eaten here before."  It was the folding chairs and filthy menus that caused me to irk at first.   

Then I look at the fish tank!  It was murky with two dead cod floating in it.  The crabs were in 2" of water and gasping!  When the chicken soup came out with lotus, I passed.  Can you imagine what's in that?  

The food was very greasy, I kept it as safe as possible.  But, was still disappointed with basic play it safe dishes.  I've eaten at just about every place in Chinatown (wife is Chinese), what the hell is saving $4-5 on your tab worth people?  Go get great food with fresh ingredients.  

I worry about some of you 4-5 stars down there.  This isn't a matter of differences of taste, or saving $ - the preservation of our human dignity is on the line - don't go here!
author: Michael R.

description:
dumpy dungeon restaurant in Chinatown basement.
ordered the yee wonton and it was aight. not great.
but with tax and tip it was $8 out the door.
when did c-town get so pricey?
not likely to come back here.
author: Jeff W.

description: One of the best Chinese restaurant in SF. The staff is very friendly and the food is excellent. I recommend to take the menu for group where you can taste many different dishes with your friends or family. I recommend the Beef Broccoli.
author: Nader S.

description:
We were given chores to complete in Chinatown.  I am not Asian and do not like Asian food.  I do, however, like Americanized Chinese food.  Chinatown does not offer this at many restaurants, and when we walked by a restaurant that had orange chicken I dragged the boy in.

The restaurant has two dining areas, one below and one above, the one above is nicer with red high-backed chairs.  The area below has glass table tops over pink table cloths and a view into their dirty-looking kitchen.

I ordered the orange chicken and my Asian partner ordered something Chinese.  My orange chicken was surprisingly very good.  Not sweet, bordering what I would call slightly hot, and the chicken was not over battered.
author: Brooke R.

description:
Well let me start by saying DO NOT ORDER THE WONTON SOUP!! Eeckkk... it had a flavor we couldn't figure out. Actually had an aftertaste that kind of settled onto the tongue. 

We were directed to the restaurant by a local minister and a few people he was standing with on the street. By the looks of it this place may be a local favorite. It wasn't ours! You go down into the basement and the tables and chairs look like a cheap diner. It had an interesting, not pleasant smell, and the decor was ... well... not very good. The host was pleasant and the waitreses (had a different one for each step of the meal) were friendly enough. 

The bathroom is up a scary flight of stairs and its a challenge to find the light switch if you go all the way into the bathroom first. (It's outside the room next to the men's door.) 

I had the hunan shrimp which had pretty good flavor. Not great but flavorful. A friend had sweet and sour chicken that was great. Then we all tried our rice and again it had the same 'off' taste as the soup. We think it might be a water problem. Either way when we left the table there was a lot of paid for food sitting there. Some because it tasted horrible and some because there are large portions. 

I wouldn't try it again but maybe it would be better with a local or Chinese friend who could advise you what to order.
author: J. M. J.

description: We loved the pot stickers, walnut shrimp, and fried rice.  I'm glad we discovered it!
author: Alisa B.

description: Stumbled in randomly in the evening when we didn't know what to eat. Had a big plate of vegetables and chicken. The food was all right, nothing amazing. I wasn't really impressed by anything. I'm surprised I found this so easily on Yelp actually.
author: Rina L.

description:
I'm not a hater but I've never been to SF and had good, authentic chinese food.  Granted, maybe I just need to try more places.  This place is no exception to my first sentence.  It looked authentic enough, dingy hole in the wall in chinatown.  Open late on new years day when all the other american  places were closed.  I looked inside and the place was filled with chinese people, so it looked legit.

Nope, I was wrong.  I got a glance of the kitchen and it was even made by chinese people, but for some reason, the chinese food in LA is way better!  The food here was a bit bland and just not prepared as fresh as I like it.  It tastes like a lot of the food was bought at a chinese supermarket and just reheated really quickly, without even trying to add anymore flavor or anything else to it.  

No need to come here again.  If there are any other places to try, please let me know... I would like to be proven wrong.
author: Lisa D.

description: More like 3.5 stars.  After walking around Chinatown, we decided to try Chef Hung's because of it's name.  We figured, if he named the restaurant after himself, it must be good.  I was not disappointed.  The food was good, the prices were cheap, and the portions were very large.  This is definitely a hole in the wall place that can be easily missed.  It's on a side street and you have to go down steps to get to the restaurant.  I can't compare it to other Chinese restaurants in San Francisco, since I'm not a local, but I was definitely pleased with Chef Hung's.
author: Judy C.

description:
This place was really great. This was by far the best Chow Mien I have ever tasted! Hands down.

The Sweet and Sour chicken was amazing. 

Not all the dishes were equally as good.... so I think it would take a couple visits to get the menu down. 

As you leave the owner greets you and makes sure your meal was good.... which is a nice touch. 

Warning: This restaurant is SUPER cold. Either they don't have any heat, or don't turn it on, so make sure to bring a sweater.
author: Cody R.

description:
I want to like this place.   Once upon a time, this place was called Great Wall and it was our favorite place because they had some really really good authentic dishes.  Sorry, back to the present...

We walked by few weeks ago to check out the menu and thought about coming here then decided against it.  Since then, hubby was talking to his stylist about restaurants and he said this place is pretty good.  Ok, maybe we will give it a try.

The place looks the same so it's comforting.  There are many bright colored paper with specials on the walls, like most other Chinese restaurants.  Here, they categorize them by meat so there is about 7-10 specials per meat (pork, beef, poultry, seafood...etc.).  Some dishes are just pure soul food and we tend to order them whenever we see them, they just bring back good memories although most places never cook like mom or dad.

I never bothered with the regular menu and just ordered from the specials on the wall.  As usual, I wanted much more than we can have and the waitress stopped me when I ordered 4 dishes.  Unfortunately, one item was out so I only ended up with 3 but it was more than enough as the portion is very generous.

What we ordered:
bean sprout (the large one) with pig intestine - they didn't have the ingredients but the waitress didn't tell me until I asked her.  she then insisted the 3 orders are more than enough for the two of us - fine.

black bean chicken - this was a favorite from the old place, if cooked right it is the BEST.  They did ok, it was tasty but a bit oily.  Also, it was a mix of various parts of chicken and the way they had it chopped/cut made some pieces to be a mystery.  

Fried tofu, bean curd, garlic, mushroom and cod filet - we were first amazed by the portion but that was short lived.  It was very bland.  The bean curd was not fried like we are used to and how most other restaurants do it.  The batter on the cod was too thick and the fish was not so good.  This is the first time we didn't like this dish enough to finish it or take home.

Stir fried preserved turnips with pork belly - again, big portion and it was not bad.  They must have soaked the preserved turnip for a long time because it was not very flavorful.  The sliced pork belly was not bad.

We were given their house soup (arrow root) to start and ended with dessert, red bean soup with tapioca.  

The waitress wasn't very friendly and a bit blunt.  The guy there, owner or son or owner?, was nice.  Thanks to him, we moved to the far end table 
away from their regular who has a very very very strong body odor.  Had we not moved early on, I don't think I could have stayed to eat anything.

This appears to be a regular place for a lot of first generation Chinese American.
author: Gloria H.

description: Great convenient location, but parking can be a pain if you're not already strolling about china town.   The food is tasty for inexpensive chinese food (especially the pork chow mein!), but the service has declined after this place changed ownership.  Still, Chef Hung's is a great restaurant to go with a larger group.
author: Christina S.

description:
I needed a Chinese rest. that could hold 26 5/6 graders & 20 adults w/ a good selection & an out the door price. Tom the manager was marvelous. 
When emailing ?'s he emailed me timely & gave me all of the info + more.
Organized perfectly! We were seated w children @ their tables & adults to enjoy a dinner w/out potty jokes! 
The service was impeccable. Water was brought right away- tea was served, smiles were always present. 
The food was scrumptious! We started out w the wonton soup- tasty, hot & simple. 
Salt & Pepper Chix Wings- finger lickin good
Beef w Broccoli- Broccoli still crunchy & the sauce was yummy
House Chowmein that the children killed in seconds because it was so tasty.
Lemon Chicken- this was the first plate done on every table- I was using a spoon to get the last of the sauce just to lick again.
Garlic Chicken- you must like onions & garlic- & man I do! 
Sweet & Sour Porkchops- this was the least favorite of mine but I still had a huge helping & finished it all. 
My water glass was always filled- my dirty plate removed promptly w another clean plate replaced. 

The bathrooms upstairs were clean & well stocked. 

The price was fantastic! 

The entire school group left w smiles upon their faces & a new Chinese rest. to rant about to their friends & family. 

Thank you, to the entire staff of Chef Hung's!
author: Suzanne T.

description:
The lunch specials are awesome here - all of them are less than $7, and oh my, they have Cherry 7up! And Cherry coke! 
In stock! 
All! 
The! 
Time!

Sorry for the Spartan approach.

The food is cheap, and sometimes tastes that way. But it's my go-to place for a quick rice plate (the cod with black cod with black beans is particularly tasty. Egg Foo Young is sometimes powdery).

I found it funny that I was given a fork to eat with, paired with fortune cookies at the end of a quintessential Chinatown experience - since I've been here before I knew to ask for chopsticks and jell-o like my asian brethren!
author: dj z.

description:
Me and a friend were walking around China Town looking for a place to eat lunch, but had no idea which place to go to. So I called a friend who looking up Chinese food in China Town on Yelp. Low and behold, Chef Hung's came up with an OK rating, so I thought, "Why not? Besides, when I lived in Hong Kong and traveled around Asia, I ate at whole in the wall places many times."

I must say this place was not bad. Prices were fairly cheap, place fairly clean, and food was at least ok. I actually didn't know what to get and after kind of blindly placing my order, the waitress suggested another dish similar to it, but supposedly better. Their service was pretty good. So if you're looking for a decent place to get Chinese food for lunch, try this place.
author: patrick f.

description:
(****This is not a date place, unless your date is down-to-earth and enjoys good, authentic Chinese homestyle cooking.)

My grandmother has lived in North Beach and frequented Chinatown for over 50 years and eats here all the time.  It's dingy and very hole-in-the-wall, but it's fantastic if you order the right things.  

Don't go here for the touristy Chinese food (egg rolls, fried rice, etc.).  They have great bittermelon, pork hash, gi mien, and other Cantonese homestyle dishes of that sort.  They also have very, very good American lunch dishes for $6 pop.  My fave is the roast pork--you get four pieces of tender roast pork with gravy, with white rice and veggies.  Though they don't interest me, you also get soup and dessert (usually Jello or some crap like that).
author: Kimberly Q.

description:
This is the most awful restaurant in chinatown.  I got the fried pork and the seafood noodles.  The noodles were crunchy and had maybe 3 or 4 pieces of shrimp in them.  That was the seafood.  The pork was a slab of fat and was completely inedible.  I would not feed it to a dog.

Please go somewhere else.  I'd suggest Hong Kong Clay Pot as a much better option, or any of the dim sum places.  Be smart and stay away from this place.
author: charlie n.

description:
The last two times I've traveled to San Francisco with teens I've found myself at Chef Hung's for three simple reasons.

1.  It is near our meeting space.
2.  It is cheap.
3.  It is relatively good and kids will eat here.

The lunch and dinner specials are yummy and filling and not overwhelmingly Americanized.  

Perhaps the most persuasive reason to love Chef Hung's is because written in the men's bathroom is, "Chef Hung is hung".  Vulgar - I know, but it never ceases to crack me up!
author: Amy B.

description: The food was decent, but felt extremely greasy.  Didn't help that the restaurant was heavy with the smell of urine more than food.  My fiancé and I split an order of broccoli beef that was rather bland.  Unimpressive but not awful.
author: Megan K.

description:
Haven't been to SF Chinatown for a long time. Meet up with some golf buddies I met while traveling in China and Tibet last October at this restaurant for lunch. Wow, I forgot how "cheap" you can eat in Chinatown.
This place serves real Chinese "comfort" lunch plates for around $6 each..
I had the roast pork served with rice, vegetables, soup and bread with dessert . The total tab for eight of us comes out to $8 each with tax and tip.
Unbelievable!!!!
author: Chills E.

description: Freaking Awesome Chinese food! With so many choices Chinatown can be a very confusing place to settle on where to eat at. Look no further than Chef Hung's. The food: absolutely delicious, cooked well, served hot, bursting with flavor and huge portions. The price: dirt cheap, I felt bad paying such low prices it was so cheap. We had 2 pot stickers, tea , 2 drinks, beef fried rice, pork chow mein, general chicken, Mongolian beef and soup for $40. FORTY DOLLARS!. I couldn't believe it. The Mongolian beef and fried rice were by far the best I had ever had. Now on to the only downside: Service. The servers were nice and accommodating however once they dropped off the food it took a very long time for them to come back. We had finished eating and needed some boxes and to pay and the servers were chit chatting away while stacking chairs (it was close to closing time). It wasn't bad enough to lower them a star but just don't plan on service being extremely quick.
author: Zak P.

description:
I've eaten here many times & it was one of my local regular stops in Chinatown. Wish I had reviewed it then, because the food was pretty good.

Ate here tonight after not visiting for a while. I noticed the absence of our usual cheery & friendly waitress, and the owner who would often chat with diners. Then the food came -- I had beef w/broccoli over rice & my friend had a noodle dish. Neither of them were very good or flavorful.

New owner, waitresses, & cooks, and unfortunately didn't have a good first visit here & probably won't be back any time soon. Perhaps they need time to get into a groove, but not while I'm paying to eat there.
author: D L.

description: I'm fat and Chinese.  The food here is terrible.  Fat people don't eat here and neither should you.
author: Fatty A.

description: I used to come here with a coworker and hadn't in a long time and couldn't recall why, but I figured I'd give the chef another shot.  It's another one of those underground places, so it's sort of dark since their lighting is weak.  It may just have been the item I picked Garlic Chicken rice plate, but I did not think it was very good.  The chicken quality was fine, but the taste was incredibly bland and I hardly noticed any garlic at all.  Vegetables didn't excite me.  No soup.  It's a weird place because they also serve some American dishes like Roast Beef which a lot of the Chinese patrons are seen eating.  Fortune cookie at end was actually quite good, but experience leads me to probably not return again.  (I noticed they brought jello instead for the Asian patrons so ask for it if you'd rather have that for dessert)  Still, I think maybe some of thier other dishes might rate a 3 if I ever return.  $6.50 with tip.
author: Marc S.

description:
Well, to be fair I should say that I am not a big fan of Chinese food to begin with. But since my friends dragged me here I thought I should give it another shot. BIG mistake. 

I'm actually still gagging while writing this review thinking about the food. (No kidding!)
It is absolutely tasteless, greasy and bad looking on top of it. All the dishes tasted pretty much the same, most meat entrees didn't even have any veggies on the side. 
Half of the meals were lukewarm and my stomach was just protesting with every bite. The best thing of the whole dinner was the fortune cookie. I guess that says it all,

And don't even get me started on the place itself. Neon lights, no windows, weird neon posters with specials in Chinese all over the place. I don't get it, do Chinese people really like to sit in that kind of environment??? 

Well, I sure won't be back to Chef Hungs or any other Chinese place. I've had it!
author: Mrs H.

description: We were pleasantly suprised - all the dishes were cooked and flavored just right . The staff was friendly and the service was prompt.  It's not fancy and seating can be cramped if the restaurant is full.
author: Katherine Y.

description: EXCELLENT place!! I go there quite often, the food is consistently great, very reasonably priced, and the service is fast and friendly. I highly recommend!!!
author: Joe B.

description: throughly basic Chinese place.  My Shanghainese-American friend, visiting from New York, really wanted to go and eat in Chinatown.  I groaned, knowing she would be disappointed but humored her.  Not surprisingly, she found none of the types of places that entice her in NYC though she was fascinated by the architecture.  Finally, we stumbled down into Chef Hung's, hungry and sick of climbing hills on a Sunday night.  Serviceable, enough veggie options, just dingy enough to convince my friend she wasn't in a tourist trap.  I appreciated the moderate prices and big portions. Otherwise, I won't be back -  I told my friend that next time she's in town we're eating in the Mission so she can be like a real San Francisco and enjoy some great food.
author: Gloria B.

description: Eat elsewhere!! well, I guess you can eat here if you want FRAUD!!! That's right, I said FRAUD and a hair in your food!!  My husband and I decided to eat here while we were in San Francisco for our anniversary.   I was having their wonton soup and I was almost done with the soup when I noticed a long dark hair on a wonton! It was so gross! All the waitress said was "sorry".   I was pretty disgusted and wanted to leave.  I didn't want to be to rude so I didn't complain a whole lot besides mentioning the hair.  Anyway, my husband handed the waitress the card and my husband noticed that SHE HID BEHIND A WALL.  He noticed, thought it was weird and different but didn't talk about it much after.   Well, 2 days later there was fraud done on his card and I'm like 95% sure it was them because the fraud was in San Francisco and we don't even live there! Anyway, GO ELSEWHERE!!!!! Next time, I'll be a bit more picky about where we eat!!
author: Margarita H.

description: It was OK.... the place was really dirty and smelly. one of the waitress picked up her cell phone when she was taking our order(which was SO random!!)I was really pissed! The food was OK. We had pot-stickers for appetizer which tasted like tuna and dough!!  In spite of everything this place is good for groups, the location is nice too.But i don't recommend it for people who are hard to please.
author: Lissete E.

description:
I thought I'd give this an update. Pretty much everything I said in my first review still holds, but I've got a new dish to add to my favorites list. Basically, it's stir-fried chicken over gailan (Chinese broccoli) surrounded by deep-fried chicken wings. The chicken chunks are on top of the broccoli, so it's sort of like 3 dishes on one plate. And it's quite a bit of food. I don't know how much it was as my friend paid for dinner (thanks Tony!) but it was good. If it concerns you, ask at ordering time.

We also had the stir-fried frog with chives and peanuts as mentioned in the previous review. While it didn't have the smoky flavor I've loved in the past, it was still pretty darned good.
author: Charles B.

description:
This is my favourite Chinese place in San Francisco.  We found it by wandering in China Town unsure of where to eat.  I pointed to this place and we gave it a try.  That was over a year ago and we have eaten there once a week ever since. 

It's family owned and operated which is important to me, but more than that the service is great (We always get Sam) and will recommend chef Hung to anyone looking for fresh, delicious food. 

It's not fancy - but some of the better restaurants are not and if you are more into food than ambiance, this is the place for you.
author: S. Elizabeth R.

description: Not bad, but not terribly exciting either.  I ordered one of the daily specials, fried sole, because it came with green tea and dessert.  Turns out, everyone gets free green tea anyways (which is good, but then it's misleading to list it as a benefits of ordering the special) and the "dessert" was a fortune cookie... wow!  On the other hand, it has a great location just off the the main Chinatown thoroughfare, and the food was good and cheap.  We all really liked the cabbage that came with our specials.  My sole also had a tasty and rich (but as far as a I can tell not very Chinese) spread / sauce.  This is definitely a place to go if you want to go if you want a big plate of cheap, warm food put in front of you.  After our meal, our party of five had some trouble paying the bill because it was written in Chinese characters, so we couldn't tell who owed how much.  When we asked the owner, he took a long time figuring it out and it became pretty confusing.  We should have all asked for separate checks... I never remember until it's too late!
author: Mara H.

description:
Decent food with fairly large portions and average prices. 

The meals that I have had were not spectacular by any means but they were not bad either.
author: John C.

description:
the food's okay. just..okay. and i'll be the first to tell all my fellow chinese friends NOT to come here with a group of 15/16 people all dressed in black who just went to a 6:00PM wake (as in funeral, folks). when you walk in the door, you will be greeted by the funny stares of many nonasians. beware.

i came here a couple of times. we basically order the chinese stuff...except there was this one time i wanted to try the eggroll appetizer thing, and the waitress said to my uncle in chinese, "ohh. only the foreigners order those kind of dishes!" psh. so what? i ordered it to try it out, and it was bad. so, take a tip from me: don't order the typical stuff like kung pao chicken or the eggrolls. if you think it's delicious, it probably isn't, compared with other chinese places. stick to the authentic chinese dishes, and you won't be sorry. (hm. that actually goes for any chinese restaurant you go to..)

another one of the dishes my family ordered was this fried pork dish. it tasted...weird. =/ 

the BATHROOM is scary. not the cleanest place either. 

service is kinda bad too.

thus, 2 stars. thankyou.
author: Betty T.

description: I come to this restaurant with my martial arts family.  The dishes are pretty tasty and the portions are decent.  Their specials are pretty good.  Everyday there are about 4-5 daily specials that range from 6- bucks a pop.  They range from traditional chinese dishes to more westernized dishes.  I don't really have a favorite, but the garlic chicken and roast pork are my usual dishes to get.
author: Philip L.

description:
one of the first places i went to when i first moved to san francisco, someone once told me that good chinese food in chinatown lies either up or down a half flight of stairs and being a bottom floor restaurant chef hung's is a fun nitty gritty place to go if you want a simple dinner with friends, always let the tea steep a couple moments from the time they bring it to your table b/c it's too weak otherwise.  i go back just for th fu kien style rice and the house special pan fried noodles, everything else is ok but those are the two that stand out to me and the two that keep me coming back

1 star for reasonable price 2 stars for having a lot of chinese people(if you see more americans in a place of ethnic cuisine be worried) 3 stars for the fu kien rice and pan fried noodle
author: janice b.

description: I went to celebrate my daughters birthdays on a Saturday(9/25) night. We ordered from the  fixed priced Chinese family style menu. There is large  portions of the eight dishes and the food arrived fast and hot.. Don't expect ambiance, kinda of noisy, well, Chinese family style.  It was satisfactory, not outstanding. We would probably come again since we haven't found another place that we liked that has the family dinner menu. Good for non-Asians willing to try new food besides the wonton soup, chow mein and fried rice fare. The Chinese family menu has the English translation with it. PS. It is named "NEW" Chef Hungs, a new owner has taken over since September 1st.
author: Gerry P.

description: My bf and I come here once a few months. Their seafood congee is good (add a lil soy sauce for taste)., chicken salted fish fried rice, seafood crispy noodle, red bean soup, and potstickers are good. We usually get around the same things...have not ventured out more of their huge menu.  service is cool, amibance is like any chinatown restaurant..price is pretty cheap. it's hard to find a good restaurant in chinatown, coz there's so many options! It fulfills our chinese food appetite when we're around chinatown. Oh yeah, $15 minimum for credit cards, FYI.
author: Janet W.

description: Pretty mediocre. Certainly edible, and the service was speedy and friendly.
author: Ben P.
